abstract.p: Stuart Coan letter holds we should be grateful that minorities are responding strongly to census questionnaires; says lack of cooperation by many other Americans is disturbing

block.p: We can be grateful that minorities are responding strongly to census questionnaires (front page, May 4), but the lack of cooperation by many other Americans is disturbing.
We can be grateful that minorities are responding strongly to census questionnaires (front page, May 4), but the lack of cooperation by many other Americans is disturbing.

This refusal to obey the law and assume a vital civic responsibility forces the census workers I supervise to return repeatedly to ask for answers, an expensive process. And each person not counted costs the community thousands of dollars each year in federal money that supports programs for the elderly, Head Start, veterans, hospitals, schools and many more. When federal money is unclaimed, taxpayers must dig into their own pockets to pay for programs mandated by Congress.
It is paradoxical that some who decry wasteful government spending are forcing such spending by the census and are then obliged to pay for it themselves.
